Classes

ValidatorFactory

Factory class for creating validators dynamically with type safety.

Module Contents

class type_forge.validators.factory.ValidatorFactory[source]

Factory class for creating validators dynamically with type safety.

This class provides static methods for creating various types of validators and performing validation operations with comprehensive error reporting.

The factory pattern enables consistent validator creation with proper configuration and composition, supporting both simple and complex validation scenarios.

static _get_type_name(typ)[source]

Get a human-readable name for a type or type collection.

Parameters:

typ (object) – A type, tuple of types, or list/sequence of types

Returns:

A string representation of the type(s)

Return type:

str

static _try_convert(value, target_type)[source]

Try to convert a value to the target type.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Value to convert

  • target_type (Type[V]) – Type to convert to

Returns:

Converted value or None if conversion failed

Return type:

Optional[V]

Note

This is an internal method used by validate_type.

static create_validator(validator_type, **kwargs)[source]

Creates a validator based on the specified type.

Parameters:

  • validator_type (str) – The type of validator to create. Must be one of the supported validator types (‘basic’, ‘composite’).

  • **kwargs (Dict[str, object]) – Additional parameters for the validator. Passed directly to the validator constructor.

Returns:

An instance of the requested validator.

Raises:

ValueError – If the validator type is unknown.

Return type:

Callable[[object], bool]

Examples

>>> validator = ValidatorFactory.create_validator('basic')
>>> validator(42)
True
static validate_dict(value, schema, path='$', convert=False, require_all_keys=True)[source]

Validate that a dictionary conforms to a schema.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Dictionary to validate

  • schema (type_forge.typing.hints.DictSchemaT) – Schema defining expected types for keys

  • path (str) – Current path for error reporting

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt type conversion

  • require_all_keys (bool) – Whether all schema keys must be present

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and converted dict if applicable

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[Dict[str, object]]

Examples

>>> schema = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_dict(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> data = {"name": "Bob"}  # Missing 'age'
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_dict(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
False
static validate_recursive(value, schema, path='$', convert=False)[source]

Recursively validate a value against a schema of arbitrary complexity.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – Value to validate

  • schema (type_forge.typing.hints.SchemaTypeT) – Schema to validate against (dict, list/sequence, or type)

  • path (str) – Current path for error reporting

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt type conversion

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and details

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[object]

Examples

>>> schema = {"name": str, "age": int}
>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": 30}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_recursive(data, schema)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> data = {"name": "Alice", "age": "30"}
>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_recursive(data, schema, convert=True)
>>> result.valid
True
>>> result.converted_value
{'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30}
static validate_type(value, expected_type, path='$', convert=False)[source]

Validate that a value matches the expected type recursively.

Parameters:

  • value (object) – The value to check

  • expected_type (Union[Type[type_forge.typing.hints.T], Sequence[Type[object]]]) – Type or types to check against

  • path (str) – Current path in the validation (for error reporting)

  • convert (bool) – Whether to attempt conversion to the expected type

Returns:

ValidationResult with validation status and details

Return type:

type_forge.core.base.ValidationResult[type_forge.typing.hints.T]

Examples

>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_type(42, int)
>>> result.valid
True

>>> result = ValidatorFactory.validate_type("42", int, convert=True)
>>> result.valid
True
>>> result.converted_value
42
